TEXT:
Chief Complaint: RUQ pain
   24 Hour Events:
   - had ERCP- stone were seen, not yet removed, sphinterotomy done, stent
   placed, bile with pus drained, will need repeat ERCP in 6 weeks with
   stone removal and stent removal
   - NPO for gallstone pancreatitis
   - continued IVF
   - sats 88-90% on NC 3 liters, no sx, started standing atrovent and
   albuterol nebs
   - later more SOB sating 87% on 6L NC,  had CXR showing pulmonary edema,
   gave lasix 40mg IV x 2, UO of >1000ml, and then 93% on 3L NC
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Ampicillin - [**2143-7-2**] 12:28 AM
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Omeprazole (Prilosec) - [**2143-7-1**] 08:00 PM
   Morphine Sulfate - [**2143-7-1**] 11:00 PM
   Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2143-7-2**] 12:28 AM
   Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) - [**2143-7-2**] 04:00 AM
   Other medications:

   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.3/27.6/1.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:23/3/<0.01, ALT / AST:145/63, Alk Phos / T Bili:268/4.8,
   Amylase / Lipase:/93, Differential-Neuts:81.2 %, Lymph:9.9 %, Mono:8.5
   %, Eos:0.3 %, Albumin:3.5 g/dL, LDH:309 IU/L, Ca++:7.6 mg/dL, Mg++:2.1
   mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL
   [**7-1**] RUQ U/S Final read: Choledocolithiasis or cholelithiasis
   [**7-1**] Echo: VF>55%, mild AV stenosis
   Assessment and Plan
 CHOLECYSTITIS, CALCULOUS
   77yo gentleman with CAD, HTN, and DM presenting with RUQ pain and
   obstructive LFTs concerning for cholangitis.
   # RUQ pain / Elevated LFTs:
   Clinical presentation concerning for cholangitis, although he may also
   have pancreatitis (suggested by labs but not by physical exam).  His
   imaging is suggestive of coincident cholecystitis, but he has no
   indication at present for urgent cholecystectomy.  Although biliary
   sludge or gallstones may explain all of the above findings, would also
   consider that he is an elderly gentleman with a smoking history.  It is
   unclear if his age-appropriate cancer screening is up to date.
   - continue unasyn (3g Q6H; Day 1 = [**6-30**]) but would add vancomycin to
   cover enterococcus if he clinically worsens
   - IV fluids for hydration, but will be a little less aggressive with
   boluses given mild crackles on exam (note that pt is on lasix at home,
   although the indication is unclear)
   - morphine IV for pain
   - plan for ERCP in AM
   - monitor clinical exam, VS
   - appreciate surgical input re: possibility of cholecystectomy
 NOTE
   pt wants to move to West Haven [**Hospital **] Hospital for this procedure due to
   proximity to home.
   - follow LFTs, fever curve, mental status
   - f/u blood cultures
   - f/u final reads of CT
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Pt noted to be in Afib with RVR on [**2143-7-2**]
   around 1pm, asymptomatic (no chest pain or palpitations).  Pt treated
   with lopressor 5mg x 3, diltiazem 10 mg x2, loaded with PO metoprolol.
   Initial CK and troponin c normal. 12-lead EKG with Afib.
   - review previous echo
   - continue monitoring rate
   - continue metoprolol (previously on medicaton as outpatient)
   # Low grade fevers:
   Likely due to above, but will send UA/UCx and f/u BCx in this
   diabetic.  Also note that he has a cough on exam, although he states
   this is a chronic cough for him, likely from bronchitis due to his long
   smoking history.
   .
   # HTN:
   Pt hypertensive to SBP in 230s in the ED.  Given concern for developing
   cholangitis, will hold back on giving him all of his home meds, but
   will start short-acting ACE I to prevent severe HTN.
   - captopril 12.5mg TID; titrate up as needed for goal BPs < 170/110
   - will hold patient's metoprolol for now so as not to mask tachycardic
   response
   .
   # Altered mental status:
   [**Month (only) 51**] be due to sundowning in this elderly gentleman who has been to
   multiple hospitals and received IV narcotics.  Would also be concerned
   about CO2 retention given smoking history.  Although altered mental
   status can be a marker of worsening cholangitis, he has not shown
   evidence of septic physiology, so this is less likely the culprit.
   Finally, given elevated pressures in ED, ICH is in differential.
   - CT Head to rule out bleed
   - cautious use of narcotic medications
   - check ABG
   - monitor
   .
   # DM:
   Apparently, only on oral meds at home.  Elevated glucose in ED likely
   due to infection, stress reaction.
   -          SSI for now, consider long acting insulin when transfer to
   floor
   -          Consider restarting home meds
   .
   # Mild gap acidosis:
   - lactate was normal in the ED, AG now 14
   - will monitor
   .
   # Nausea:
   Resolved, was likely related to possible cholangitis/pancreatitis.
   However, given that he is a diabetic with a history of coronary
   disease, this can be a sign of cardiac ischemia.  EKG is reassuring.
   - monitor
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG:
   - continue ASA
   - holding beta blocker as above
   - continue ACE inhibitor
   - continue statin
   .
   # PVD:
   - holding cilostazol as non-formulary med
   .
   # Question of thyroid nodule:  Per review of OSH records.
   - will check TFTs
   - follow up as outpatient
   .
   # Tobacco abuse:
   - counsel regarding tobacco cessation
   - offer nicotine patch
   - continue advair for ?? COPD; will not order equivalent of formoterol
   or mom[**Name (NI) **] as he has beta agonist and steroid in advair
   .
   # Likely dyslipidemia:
   Not on problem list from OSH records, but on statin and gemfibrozil.
   -restarted simvastatin, holding gemfibrozil until LFTs improve
   .
   # Likely BPH:  hold terazosin for now in case his BP begins to drop
   from cholangitis, but will monitor
   .
   # Anemia:  current hct 33, baseline hct not known
   - check iron studies, retics, peripheral smear
   - active type and screen given h/o GI bleed
   - stool is guaiac negative
   - monitor
   .
   # h/o Prostate CA:  resolved, per pt
   ICU [**Name (NI) 81**]
   Nutrition: started on clears
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2143-7-1**] 08:09 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  LMWH
   Stress ulcer:  Omeperazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition: Transfer to medicine floor (per surgery recommendation)

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory complications: The patient's pulmonary edema and low oxygen saturation (88-93%) may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypertension may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and stroke.
3. Infection-related complications: The patient's low-grade fevers, cough, and altered mental status may indicate the presence of a secondary infection, which could spread to other parts of the body.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's pancreatitis and cholecystitis may worsen, leading to further complications such as sepsis, organ failure, and potentially life-threatening conditions.
5. Endocrine complications: The patient's diabetes may worsen due to the stress of the illness, leading to hyperglycemia and potential complications such as ketoacidosis.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may be a sign of worsening cholangitis, sepsis, or other conditions, which could lead to seizures, coma, or other neurological deficits.
7. Hematological complications: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, malnutrition, or other factors, leading to further complications such as heart failure, respiratory failure, or increased risk of infection.
8. Renal complications: The patient's mild gap acidosis may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, or other renal complications.
9. Thyroid-related complications: The patient's thyroid nodule may be a sign of thyroid cancer or other thyroid-related complications, which could worsen if left untreated.
10. Cardiovascular medication-related complications: The patient's medications, such as beta blockers and ACE inhibitors, may interact with each other or with other medications, leading to adverse effects such as hypotension, bradycardia, or cardiac arrest.

The patient's medical history, current medications, and laboratory results indicate a complex and multifaceted condition that requires close monitoring and management to prevent these complications from arising or worsening.

Summary:

The patient is a 77-year-old gentleman with a history of CAD, HTN, and DM, admitted to the ICU with RUQ pain and elevated LFTs concerning for cholangitis. He underwent ERCP with sphinterotomy, stent placement, and drainage of bile with pus. He is currently receiving IVF, oxygen therapy, and medications for pain, nausea, and hypertension. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, and his current EKG shows Afib with RVR. He has also been experiencing low-grade fevers, which are likely due to the infection. His mental status has improved, but he has a history of altered mental status due to sundowning and CO2 retention.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cholangitis: The patient's RUQ pain and elevated LFTs are concerning for cholangitis, and he is at risk for developing sepsis and multi-organ failure if not treated promptly.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest the possibility of pancreatitis, which can lead to complications such as pancreatic necrosis, abscesses, and sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen therapy and respiratory support may not be sufficient to manage his respiratory failure, and he may require mechanical ventilation.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD, atrial fibrillation, and hypertension put him at risk for cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
5. Infection: The patient's low-grade fevers and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of infection, which can lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of GI bleed and his current use of anticoagulant therapy put him at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's history of altered mental status and his current use of sedatives and analgesics put him at risk for neurological complications such as seizures, delirium, and coma.
8. Renal failure: The patient's history of hypertension and his current use of diuretics and ACE inhibitors put him at risk for renal failure.
9. Hepatic failure: The patient's elevated LFTs and his current use of anticoagulant therapy put him at risk for hepatic failure.
10. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's history of malnutrition and his current use of IVF may put him at risk for nutritional deficiencies.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's RUQ pain and LFTs to assess the severity of his cholangitis.
2. Consider repeating ERCP to remove the stone and stent.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy and respiratory support as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension and cardiac status.
5. Monitor the patient's infection and adjust his antibiotic therapy as needed.
6. Consider restarting his home medications, including his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications.
7. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his IVF as needed.
8. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist and a cardiologist to assess the patient's condition and develop a plan for his further management.

 CHOLECYSTITIS, CALCULOUS
   77yo gentleman with CAD, HTN, and DM presenting with RUQ pain and
   obstructive LFTs concerning for cholangitis.
   .
   # RUQ pain / Elevated LFTs:
   Clinical presentation concerning for cholangitis, although he may also
   have pancreatitis (suggested by labs but not by physical exam).  His
   imaging is suggestive of coincident cholecystitis, but he has no
   indication at present for urgent cholecystectomy.  Although biliary
   sludge or gallstones may explain all of the above findings, would also
   consider that he is an elderly gentleman with a smoking history.  It is
   unclear if his age-appropriate cancer screening is up to date.
   - continue unasyn (3g Q6H; Day 1 = [**6-30**]) but would add vancomycin to
   cover enterococcus if he clinically worsens
   - IV fluids for hydration, but will be a little less aggressive with
   boluses given mild crackles on exam (note that pt is on lasix at home,
   although the indication is unclear)
   - morphine IV for pain
   - plan for ERCP in AM
   - monitor clinical exam, VS
   - appreciate surgical input re: possibility of cholecystectomy
   - follow LFTs, fever curve, mental status
   - f/u blood cultures
   - f/u final reads of CT and ultrasound
   .
   # Low grade fevers:
   Likely due to above, but will send UA/UCx and f/u BCx in this
   diabetic.  Also note that he has a cough on exam, although he states
   this is a chronic cough for him, likely from bronchitis due to his long
   smoking history.
   .
   # HTN:
   Pt hypertensive to SBP in 230s in the ED.  Given concern for developing
   cholangitis, will hold back on giving him all of his home meds, but
   will start short-acting ACE I to prevent severe HTN.
   - captopril 12.5mg TID; titrate up as needed for goal BPs < 170/110
   - will hold patient's metoprolol for now so as not to mask tachycardic
   response
   .
   # Altered mental status:
   [**Month (only) 51**] be due to sundowning in this elderly gentleman who has been to
   multiple hospitals and received IV narcotics.  Would also be concerned
   about CO2 retention given smoking history.  Although altered mental
   status can be a marker of worsening cholangitis, he has not shown
   evidence of septic physiology, so this is less likely the culprit.
   Finally, given elevated pressures in ED, ICH is in differential.
   - CT Head to rule out bleed
   - cautious use of narcotic medications
   - check ABG
   - monitor
   .
   # DM:
   Apparently, only on oral meds at home.  Elevated glucose in ED likely
   due to infection, stress reaction.
   - SSI for now, but may need long acting insulin if sugars are poorly
   controlled
   .
   # Mild gap acidosis:
   - lactate was normal in the ED
   - recheck ABG with lactate
   .
   # Nausea:
   Likely related to possible cholangitis/pancreatitis.  However, given
   that he is a diabetic with a history of coronary disease, this can be a
   sign of cardiac ischemia.  EKG is reassuring.
   - check cardiac biomarkers in AM
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG:
   - continue ASA
   - holding beta blocker as above
   - continue ACE inhibitor
   - restarted statin
   .
   # PVD:
   - holding cilostazol as non-formulary med
   .
   # Question of thyroid nodule:  Per review of OSH records.
   - will check TFTs
   .
   # Tobacco abuse:
   - counsel regarding tobacco cessation
   - offer nicotine patch
   - continue advair for ?? COPD; will not order equivalent of formoterol
   or mom[**Name (NI) **] as he has beta agonist and steroid in advair
   .
   # Likely dyslipidemia:
   Not on problem list from OSH records, but on statin and gemfibrozil.
   -restarted simvastatin, holding gemfibrozil until LFTs improve
   .
   # Likely BPH:  hold terazosin for now in case his BP begins to drop
   from cholangitis, but will monitor
   .
   # Anemia:  current hct 33, baseline hct not known
   - check iron studies, retics, peripheral smear
   - active type and screen given h/o GI bleed
   - stool is guaiac negative
   - monitor
   .
   # h/o Prostate CA:  resolved, per pt
   ICU [**Name (NI) 81**]
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Summary:

The patient is a 77-year-old male with a history of CAD, HTN, and DM, who presented to the emergency department with RUQ pain and obstructive LFTs concerning for cholangitis. He underwent ERCP, which revealed a stone, and a sphincterotomy was performed with stent placement and drainage of bile with pus. He was diagnosed with cholecystitis, calculous, and pancreatitis. The patient is currently in the ICU with ongoing management of his condition, including IV fluids, morphine for pain, and antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cholangitis: The patient's condition is still concerning for cholangitis, and further monitoring and management are necessary to prevent complications.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen, leading to complications such as pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, or sepsis.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's pulmonary edema and SOB may worsen, requiring mechanical ventilation and further management.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's CAD and HTN increase his risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Infection: The patient's diabetes and history of GI bleed increase his risk for infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, potentially leading to seizures, coma, or other neurological complications.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's cholecystitis and pancreatitis may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction, perforation, or hemorrhage.
8. Hemorrhagic Complications: The patient's history of GI bleed and anemia increase his risk for hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding from the pancreatitis or cholecystitis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely, paying attention to any changes in his vital signs, mental status, or laboratory values.
2. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy as prescribed.
3. Manage the patient's pain and discomfort with morphine and other analgesics as needed.
4. Continue IV fluids and electrolyte replacement as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, considering cardiac biomarkers and ECG changes.
6. Consider further imaging studies, such as CT or MRI, to assess the extent of the patient's pancreatic and biliary disease.
7. Consider surgical consultation for possible cholecystectomy or pancreatic drainage.
8. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider enteral or parenteral nutrition as necessary.

   Apparently, only on oral meds at home.  Elevated glucose in ED likely
   due to infection, stress reaction.
   -          SSI for now, consider long acting insulin when transfer to
   floor
   -          Consider restarting home meds
   .
   # Mild gap acidosis:
   - lactate was normal in the ED, AG now 14
   - will monitor
   .
   # Nausea:
   Resolved, was likely related to possible cholangitis/pancreatitis.
   However, given that he is a diabetic with a history of coronary
   disease, this can be a sign of cardiac ischemia.  EKG is reassuring.
   - monitor
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG:
   - continue ASA
   - holding beta blocker as above
   - continue ACE inhibitor
   - continue statin
   .
   # PVD:
   - holding cilostazol as non-formulary med
   .
   # Question of thyroid nodule:  Per review of OSH records.
   - will check TFTs
   - follow up as outpatient
   .
   # Tobacco abuse:
   - counsel regarding tobacco cessation
   - offer nicotine patch
   - continue advair for ?? COPD; will not order equivalent of formoterol
   or mom[**Name (NI) **] as he has beta agonist and steroid in advair
   .
   # Likely dyslipidemia:
   Not on problem list from OSH records, but on statin and gemfibrozil.
   -restarted simvastatin, holding gemfibrozil until LFTs improve
   .
   # Likely BPH:  hold terazosin for now in case his BP begins to drop
   from cholangitis, but will monitor
   .
   # Anemia:  current hct 33, baseline hct not known
   - check iron studies, retics, peripheral smear
   - active type and screen given h/o GI bleed
   - stool is guaiac negative
   - monitor
   .
   # h/o Prostate CA:  resolved, per pt

Summary:

The patient is a 77-year-old gentleman with a history of CAD, HTN, and DM who presented to the ICU with RUQ pain and elevated LFTs concerning for cholangitis. He underwent ERCP, which showed a stone in the bile duct and pus in the bile, and was treated with sphincterotomy, stent placement, and drainage of the bile. He also has pancreatitis and is at risk for developing cholangitis. He has a history of smoking and has been experiencing low-grade fevers, which may be related to his underlying conditions. He is hypertensive and has been started on short-acting ACE I to prevent severe HTN. He also has altered mental status, which may be due to sundowning, CO2 retention, or ICH. He has been started on IV fluids and morphine for pain.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cholangitis: The patient is at risk for developing cholangitis due to the presence of a stone in the bile duct and pus in the bile. This may lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis, which may worsen and lead to complications such as necrosis, abscesses, and sepsis.
3. Hypertension: The patient is hypertensive and has been started on short-acting ACE I to prevent severe HTN. However, he may still be at risk for developing hypertensive crisis, which can lead to stroke, heart failure, and death.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to sundowning, CO2 retention, or ICH. This may lead to confusion, disorientation, and difficulty with communication and decision-making.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient has mild pulmonary edema and is at risk for developing respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and death.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has a history of CAD and has been started on statin and ACE I. He may still be at risk for developing cardiovascular complications such as MI, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of smoking and has been experiencing low-grade fevers. He may still be at risk for developing infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has pancreatitis and is at risk for developing gastrointestinal complications such as necrosis, abscesses, and perforation.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's RUQ pain and LFTs to assess for worsening cholangitis.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatitis and pancreatitis-related complications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's hypertension and adjust his medications as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's altered mental status and adjust his medications as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust his medications as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and adjust his antibiotics as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his medications as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of respiratory distress due to acute pulmonary edema. The patient has a history of cholecystitis, cholangitis, and pancreatitis, and is currently receiving treatment for these conditions.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38.2C (100.7F)
* Heart rate: 62 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 163/45 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* White blood cell count: 10.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 147 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: potassium 3.9 mEq/L, sodium 138 mEq/L, chloride 17 mg/dL

The patient is receiving treatment for respiratory distress, including oxygen therapy and diuresis. They are also receiving treatment for cholecystitis and pancreatitis, including antibiotics and antacids.

The patient's physical examination is notable for the following:

* General appearance: well-nourished, obese
* Cardiovascular examination: normal heart sounds, no murmurs
* Respiratory examination: clear lung fields, no wheezing or rhonchi
* Abdominal examination: soft, non-tender, with bowel sounds present
* Neurological examination: alert, oriented, and responding to verbal stimuli

The patient's laboratory results are notable for the following:

* Elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, and alkaline phosphatase)
* Elevated lipase levels, consistent with pancreatitis
* Elevated creatinine levels, consistent with kidney damage

The patient's assessment and plan are as follows:

* Cholecystitis and cholangitis: treated with antibiotics and antacids
* Respiratory distress: treated with oxygen therapy and diuresis
* Pancreatitis: treated with antacids and monitored for progression
* Fluid management: replete to maintain a net negative fluid balance
* Nutritional support: NPO until further evaluation
* ICU care: continued monitoring and treatment of the patient's condition

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: due to the patient's acute pulmonary edema and respiratory distress
* Sepsis: due to the patient's cholecystitis and pancreatitis
* Kidney damage: due to the patient's elevated creatinine levels and potential for acute kidney injury
* Pancreatitis: due to the patient's elevated lipase levels and potential for pancreatitis
* Nutritional deficiencies: due to the patient's NPO status and potential for malnutrition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of respiratory distress due to acute pulmonary edema. The patient has undergone ERCP and placement of a stent yesterday, and is currently receiving treatment for sepsis, respiratory distress, and other conditions.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.2C (100.7F) at 12 AM, and 37.7C (99.8F) at 11:47 AM
* Heart rate: 62 bpm
* Blood pressure: 163/45 mmHg at 12 AM, and 125/27 mmHg at 11:47 AM
* Respiratory rate: 27 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Overweight/obese, no acute distress
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Head, ears, nose, and throat: Normocephalic, no poor dentition, no endotracheal tube, no NG tube, no OG tube
* Cardiovascular: Normal pulse, no murmurs, no rub
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds, no crackles, no wheezes
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present, distended
* Extremities: Right and left radial pulses present, no cyanosis, no clubbing
* Skin: Warm, no rash, no jaundice
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, oriented to self and environment

Laboratory results include:

* White blood cell count: 10.2-12.0 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 33.2-34.2%
* Platelet count: 147-141 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9-1.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* TCO2: 24 mmHg
* Glucose: [not specified]

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Sepsis: Empirical Unasyn treatment
* Respiratory distress: Continue usual meds including lasix
* RUQ pain: Cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, may have passed stone based on clinical symptoms and LFTs. General Surgery evaluated and following.
* Fluids: Replete, monitor I/O, desire net negative fluid balance.
* Elevated LFTs: Replete to K >4.0
* Elevated lipase: Evidence of pancreatitis (chemical), monitor, NPO until evaluation complete.
* Altered mental status: Resolved, likely related to medications (narcotics)
* Hypokalemia: Replete to K >4.0
* Nutritional support: NPO.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to ongoing respiratory distress
* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Pancreatitis-related complications (e.g., abscess, necrosis)
* Cholecystitis-related complications (e.g., perforation, abscess)
* Hypokalemia-related arrhythmias or muscle weakness
* Electrolyte imbalances (e.g., hyperkalemia, hypokalemia)
* Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances)

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

Based on the patient's laboratory results and vital signs, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan
 CHOLECYSTITIS, CALCULOUS
   77yo gentleman with CAD, HTN, and DM presenting with RUQ pain and
   obstructive LFTs concerning for cholangitis.
   # RUQ pain / Elevated LFTs:
   Clinical presentation concerning for cholangitis, although he may also
   have pancreatitis (suggested by labs but not by physical exam).  His
   imaging is suggestive of coincident cholecystitis, but he has no
   indication at present for urgent cholecystectomy.  Although biliary
   sludge or gallstones may explain all of the above findings, would also
   consider that he is an elderly gentleman with a smoking history.  It is
   unclear if his age-appropriate cancer screening is up to date.
   - continue unasyn (3g Q6H; Day 1 = [**6-30**]) but would add vancomycin to
   cover enterococcus if he clinically worsens
   - IV fluids for hydration, but will be a little less aggressive with
   boluses given mild crackles on exam (note that pt is on lasix at home,
   although the indication is unclear)
   - morphine IV for pain
   - plan for ERCP in AM
   - monitor clinical exam, VS
   - appreciate surgical input re: possibility of cholecystectomy
 NOTE
   pt wants to move to West Haven [**Hospital **] Hospital for this procedure due to
   proximity to home.
   - follow LFTs, fever curve, mental status
   - f/u blood cultures
   - f/u final reads of CT
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Pt noted to be in Afib with RVR on [**2143-7-2**]
   around 1pm, asymptomatic (no chest pain or palpitations).  Pt treated
   with lopressor 5mg x 3, diltiazem 10 mg x2, loaded with PO metoprolol.
   Initial CK and troponin c normal. 12-lead EKG with Afib.
   - review previous echo
   - continue monitoring rate
   - continue metoprolol (previously on medicaton as outpatient)
   - check second set of CE
s at 9pm
   # Low grade fevers:
   Likely due to above, but will send UA/UCx and f/u BCx in this
   diabetic.  Also note that he has a cough on exam, although he states
   this is a chronic cough for him, likely from bronchitis due to his long
   smoking history.
   .
   # HTN:
   Pt hypertensive to SBP in 230s in the ED.  Given concern for developing
   cholangitis, will hold back on giving him all of his home meds, but
   will start short-acting ACE I to prevent severe HTN.
   - captopril 12.5mg TID; titrate up as needed for goal BPs < 170/110
   - was holding metoprolol to avoid masking tachycardia, however, due to
   Afib metoprolol started.
   .
   # Altered mental status:
   Pt. no longer altered.  [**Month (only) 51**] be due to sundowning in this elderly
   gentleman who has been to multiple hospitals and received IV
   narcotics.  Would also be concerned about CO2 retention given smoking
   history.  Although altered mental status can be a marker of worsening
   cholangitis, he has not shown evidence of septic physiology, so this is
   less likely the culprit.  Finally, given elevated pressures in ED, ICH
   is in differential.
   - cautious use of narcotic medications
   - monitor
   .
   # DM:
   Apparently, only on oral meds at home.  Elevated glucose in ED likely
   due to infection, stress reaction.
   -          SSI for now, consider long acting insulin when transfer to
   floor
   -          Consider restarting home meds
   -          Verify home meds with significant other
   .
   # Mild gap acidosis:
   - lactate was normal in the ED, AG now 14
   - will monitor
   .
   # Nausea:
   Resolved, was likely related to possible cholangitis/pancreatitis.
   However, given that he is a diabetic with a history of coronary
   disease, this can be a sign of cardiac ischemia.  EKG is reassuring.
   - monitor
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG:
   - continue ASA
   - continue ACE inhibitor
   - continue statin
   .
   # PVD:
   - holding cilostazol as non-formulary med
   .
   # Question of thyroid nodule:  Per review of OSH records.
   - will check TFTs
   - follow up as outpatient
   .
   # Tobacco abuse:
   - counsel regarding tobacco cessation
   - offer nicotine patch
   - continue advair for ?? COPD; will not order equivalent of formoterol
   or mom[**Name (NI) **] as he has beta agonist and steroid in advair
   .
   # Likely dyslipidemia:
   Not on problem list from OSH records, but on statin and gemfibrozil.
   -restarted simvastatin, holding gemfibrozil until LFTs improve
   .
   # Likely BPH:  hold terazosin for now in case his BP begins to drop
   from cholangitis, but will monitor
   .
   # Anemia:  current hct 33, baseline hct not known
   - check iron studies, retics, peripheral smear
   - active type and screen given h/o GI bleed
   - stool is guaiac negative
   - monitor
   .
   # h/o Prostate CA:  resolved, per pt

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 77-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a history of smoking. He is currently admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of cholecystitis, calculous, and atrial fibrillation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C, heart rate of 122 bpm, and blood pressure of 148/68 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 94% on nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, with an AST of 145 IU/L and an ALT of 63 IU/L. His white blood cell count is 10.2 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 147 x 10^9/L. His troponin T level is 0.03 ng/mL, and his creatinine level is 0.9 mg/dL.

The patient's medical history is significant for cholecystitis, calculous, and atrial fibrillation, and he is currently being treated with antibiotics and antiplatelet agents. He is also being monitored for signs of sepsis and cardiac ischemia.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes suggest the possibility of sepsis. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect early signs of sepsis.
2. Cardiac ischemia: The patient's atrial fibrillation and elevated troponin T level suggest the possibility of cardiac ischemia. Close monitoring of his electrocardiogram and cardiac enzymes is necessary to detect early signs of cardiac ischemia.
3. Cholangitis: The patient's diagnosis of cholecystitis, calculous, suggests the possibility of cholangitis. Close monitoring of his liver enzymes and imaging studies is necessary to detect early signs of cholangitis.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated amylase and lipase levels suggest the possibility of pancreatitis. Close monitoring of his abdominal pain and laboratory results is necessary to detect early signs of pancreatitis.
5. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and current blood pressure of 148/68 mmHg suggest the possibility of hypertension. Close monitoring of his blood pressure and use of antihypertensive agents is necessary to control his blood pressure.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. Close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies is necessary to detect early signs of sepsis, cardiac ischemia, cholangitis, pancreatitis, and hypertension.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan
 CHOLECYSTITIS, CALCULOUS
   77yo gentleman with CAD, HTN, and DM presenting with RUQ pain and
   obstructive LFTs concerning for cholangitis.
   # RUQ pain / Elevated LFTs:
   Clinical presentation concerning for cholangitis vs pancreatitis
   (suggested by labs but not by physical exam).  Imaging was consistent
   with coincident cholecystitis, but he had no indication at present for
   urgent cholecystectomy.  s/p ERCP with sphincterotomy and stent
   placement (see ERCP report for further results).  He is clinically
   improved and is experiencing no further abdominal discomfort.
   - continue unasyn (3g Q6H; Day 1 = [**6-30**]) but would add vancomycin to
   cover enterococcus if he clinically worsens
   - appreciate surgical input re: possibility of cholecystectomy who
   agree with plan to transfer patient as per request to West Haven VA
   - follow LFTs, fever curve, mental status
   - f/u final reads of CT
   -pt will need repeat ERCP in 6 weeks to pull billiary stent
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Pt noted to be in Afib with RVR on [**2143-7-2**]
   around 1pm, asymptomatic (no chest pain or palpitations).  Pt treated
   with lopressor 5mg x 3, diltiazem 10 mg x2, loaded with PO metoprolol.
   CK normal with troponin leak. 12-lead EKG with Afib.  Patient developed
   hypotension with increase dose metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
   - etiology: unclear whether new onset vs. paroxysmal Afib (enlarged
   LAE); will check VA records
   - continue monitoring rate
   - start digoxin for better rate control, monitor and replete K as
   needed
   -contraindication to anticoagulation as patient has had hx of recent GI
   bleed [**2-11**] to gastric ulcer
   # Low grade fevers:
   Likely due to above, but will send UA/UCx and f/u BCx in this
   diabetic.  Also note that he has a cough on exam, although he states
   this is a chronic cough for him, likely from bronchitis due to his long
   smoking history.
   .
   #  labile BP: HTN with transint episode of hypotension responsive to
   fluid bolus
   -initially received captopril [**2-11**] HTN in ER
   - hx. of HTN on home metoprolol- increased dose to 50mg TID for blood
   pressure and rate control
   ..
   # DM: poor control on SSI
   - patient
s outpatient medication held on hospitalization
   - added glargine 5 Units daily, adjust as needed to maintain euglycemia
   # CAD s/p CABG:
   - continue ASA, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold for now
   .
   # PVD: holding cilostazol as non-formulary med
   .
   # Question of thyroid nodule:  Per review of OSH records.
   - will check TFTs
   - follow up as outpatient
   .
   # Tobacco abuse:
   - counsel regarding tobacco cessation
   - offer nicotine patch
   - continue advair for ?? COPD; will not order equivalent of formoterol
   or mom[**Name (NI) **] as he has beta agonist and steroid in advair
   .
   # Likely dyslipidemia:
   Not on problem list from OSH records, but on statin and gemfibrozil.
   -restarted simvastatin, holding gemfibrozil until LFTs improve
   .
   # Likely BPH:  hold terazosin for now in case his BP begins to drop
   from cholangitis, but will monitor
   .
   # Anemia:  current hct 33, baseline hct not known
   - check iron studies, retics, peripheral smear
   - active type and screen given h/o GI bleed
   - stool is guaiac negative
   - monitor
   .
   # h/o Prostate CA:  resolved, per pt
   ICU [**Name (NI) 81**]
   Nutrition: advance to normal diet
   Glycemic Control:  glargine and SSI
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2143-7-1**] 08:09 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Heparin
   Stress ulcer: omeprazole
   VAP:

   Communication:  Comments:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 77-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted to the ICU with cholecystitis, calculous, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs) concerning for cholangitis.

The patient's current condition is stable, with an improved oxygen saturation of 94% on nasal cannula. His atrial fibrillation (Afib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR) is being treated with diltiazem and metoprolol. His troponin levels are mildly elevated, and he is at risk for cardiac complications.

The patient's fluid balance is negative, with a total fluid input of 1,535 mL and a total fluid output of 2,905 mL, resulting in a net fluid loss of 1,370 mL. His blood pressure is labile, with episodes of hypertension and hypotension, and he is at risk for cardiac and renal complications.

The patient's respiratory support consists of oxygen delivery via nasal cannula, and his ABG results are pending. His physical examination reveals scleral icterus, PERRL, and a systolic ejection murmur.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, as well as elevated troponin and creatinine levels. His electrolyte levels are normal, except for a slightly low potassium level.

The patient's medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, as well as a recent history of gastrointestinal bleeding. He is also at risk for thyroid nodule and dyslipidemia.

The patient's medications include metoprolol, diltiazem, glargine, and simvastatin, among others. He is also receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and myocardial infarction, due to his atrial fibrillation, elevated troponin levels, and labile blood pressure.
2. Respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure, due to his positive fluid balance, elevated troponin levels, and labile blood pressure.
3. Renal complications, such as acute kidney injury (AKI), chronic kidney disease (CKD), and electrolyte imbalance, due to his elevated creatinine levels, fluid imbalance, and labile blood pressure.
4. Hepatic complications, such as acute liver failure (ALF), chronic liver disease (CLD), and liver abscess, due to his elevated liver enzymes, cholecystitis, and calculous.
5. Gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction, due to his recent history of gastrointestinal bleeding and cholecystitis.
6. Endocrine complications, such as thyroid storm, hypothyroidism, and hyperthyroidism, due to his history of thyroid nodule and labile blood pressure.
7. Infectious complications, such as sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure, due to his elevated troponin levels, labile blood pressure, and positive fluid balance.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to address his atrial fibrillation, cholecystitis, calculous, and other medical conditions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical conditions. The patient's 24-hour events include the development of atrial fibrillation, which was treated with a beta-blocker, and transient hypotension that resolved with an IV fluid bolus.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.5C (99.5F)
* Heart rate: 106 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 86/51 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Overweight/obese, no acute distress
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Cardiovascular: Normal pulse, no murmurs
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds
* Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: No cyanosis, no clubbing

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 147 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* LDH: 309 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 1.8 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Sepsis, likely related to cholangitis and cholescystitis, treated with empirical Unasyn
* Atrial fibrillation, treated with a beta-blocker, with consideration for cardiology consultation and anticoagulation
* Cardiac distress, attributed to acute pulmonary edema, treated with usual medications including lasix
* RUQ pain, attributed to cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis, being evaluated by General Surgery and ERCP team
* Fluids: replete, with a goal of net negative fluid balance
* Elevated LFTs, treated with fluids and electrolyte replacement
* Elevated lipase, evidence of pancreatitis, improved
* Nutritional support: NPO
* ICU care: nutrition, glycemic control, lines, prophylaxis, stress ulcer, and VAP prevention

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis and organ failure
* Atrial fibrillation and cardiac arrest
* Cardiac distress and acute pulmonary edema
* RUQ pain and complications related to cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis
* Pancreatitis and pancreatic necrosis
* Electrolyte imbalance and hypokalemia
* Nutritional deficiencies and malnutrition
* VAP and respiratory failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure the patient's optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history. The patient has developed atrial fibrillation (A-fib) and has been experiencing chest pain, which has been attributed to coronary artery disease (CAD). The patient has also been experiencing respiratory distress, which has been attributed to acute pulmonary edema. Additionally, the patient has been experiencing right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, which has been attributed to cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 106 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 86/51 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and their oxygen saturation is 95%. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and elevated lipase levels, which are indicative of pancreatitis.

The patient's medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and cholecystitis. The patient has also been experiencing altered mental status, which has been attributed to medications. The patient's nutritional support is currently NPO, and their glycemic control is being monitored.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease put them at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's acute pulmonary edema and respiratory distress put them at risk for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis put them at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation and sepsis.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated lipase levels and laboratory results suggest pancreatitis, which can lead to complications such as sepsis, organ failure, and death.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypokalemia and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels put them at risk for electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
6. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and laboratory results suggest infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's NPO status and lack of nutritional support put them at risk for nutritional deficiencies, which can lead to weakness, fatigue, and other complications.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of their condition to prevent and treat potential complications. The patient should be closely monitored for signs of cardiac, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and pancreatic complications, as well as electrolyte imbalance and infection. The patient's nutritional support should be reevaluated and adjusted as necessary to ensure adequate nutrition and prevent nutritional deficiencies.

The patient has received multiple medications, including metoprolol, haldol, and ativan, due to agitation and delirium. The patient's lab results indicate:

* Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 147-273 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.4-0.9 mg/dL

The patient has a history of cholecystitis, both calculous and acalculous, and is currently being treated with antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 98% on nasal cannula oxygen.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's history of cholecystitis and antibiotics, there is a risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's atrial fibrillation and respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute increase the risk of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and use of medications such as metoprolol and haldol increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and platelet count fluctuations increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and use of antibiotics increase the risk of infection.
6. Delirium: The patient's agitation and use of medications such as haldol and ativan increase the risk of delirium.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of cholecystitis and use of antibiotics increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications such as diarrhea or constipation.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
 CHOLECYSTITIS, CALCULOUS
   77yo gentleman with CAD, HTN, and DM presenting with RUQ pain and
   obstructive LFTs concerning for cholangitis.
   # RUQ pain / Elevated LFTs:
   Clinical presentation concerning for cholangitis vs pancreatitis
   (suggested by labs but not by physical exam).  Imaging was consistent
   with coincident cholecystitis, but he had no indication at present for
   urgent cholecystectomy.  s/p ERCP with sphincterotomy and stent
   placement (see ERCP report for further results).  He is clinically
   improved and is experiencing no further abdominal discomfort.
   - continue unasyn (3g Q6H; Day 1 = [**6-30**]) but would add vancomycin to
   cover enterococcus if he clinically worsens
   - appreciate surgical input re: possibility of cholecystectomy who
   agree with plan to transfer patient as per request to West Haven VA
   - follow LFTs, fever curve, mental status
   - f/u final reads of CT
   -pt will need repeat ERCP in 6 weeks to pull billiary stent
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Pt noted to be in Afib with RVR on [**2143-7-2**]
   around 1pm, asymptomatic (no chest pain or palpitations).  Pt treated
   with lopressor 5mg x 3, diltiazem 10 mg x2, loaded with PO metoprolol.
   CK normal with troponin leak. 12-lead EKG with Afib.  Patient developed
   hypotension with increase dose metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
   - etiology: unclear whether new onset vs. paroxysmal Afib (enlarged
   LAE); will check VA records
   - continue monitoring rate
   - start digoxin for better rate control, monitor and replete K as
   needed
   -contraindication to anticoagulation as patient has had hx of recent GI
   bleed [**2-11**] to gastric ulcer
   # Low grade fevers:
   Likely due to above, but will send UA/UCx and f/u BCx in this
   diabetic.  Also note that he has a cough on exam, although he states
   this is a chronic cough for him, likely from bronchitis due to his long
   smoking history.
   .
   #  labile BP: HTN with transint episode of hypotension responsive to
   fluid bolus
   -initially received captopril [**2-11**] HTN in ER
   - hx. of HTN on home metoprolol- increased dose to 50mg TID for blood
   pressure and rate control
   ..
   # DM: poor control on SSI
   - patient
s outpatient medication held on hospitalization
   - added glargine 5 Units daily, adjust as needed to maintain euglycemia
   # CAD s/p CABG:
   - continue ASA, statin
   - ACE inhibitor on hold for now
   .
   # PVD: holding cilostazol as non-formulary med
   .
   # Question of thyroid nodule:  Per review of OSH records.
   - will check TFTs
   - follow up as outpatient
   .
   # Tobacco abuse:
   - counsel regarding tobacco cessation
   - offer nicotine patch
   - continue advair for ?? COPD; will not order equivalent of formoterol
   or mom[**Name (NI) **] as he has beta agonist and steroid in advair
   .
   # Likely dyslipidemia:
   Not on problem list from OSH records, but on statin and gemfibrozil.
   -restarted simvastatin, holding gemfibrozil until LFTs improve
   .
   # Likely BPH:  hold terazosin for now in case his BP begins to drop
   from cholangitis, but will monitor
   .
   # Anemia:  current hct 33, baseline hct not known
   - check iron studies, retics, peripheral smear
   - active type and screen given h/o GI bleed
   - stool is guaiac negative
   - monitor
   .
   # h/o Prostate CA:  resolved, per pt
   ICU [**Name (NI) 81**]
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:
   22 Gauge - [**2143-7-3**] 09:12 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparine proph
   Stress ulcer:  omeprazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 77-year-old gentleman with a history of CAD, HTN, and DM, who was admitted to the ICU with RUQ pain and obstructive LFTs concerning for cholangitis. The patient underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy and stent placement, and is clinically improved.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

1. Cholangitis: The patient's cholangitis can worsen, leading to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation can lead to heart failure, stroke, and cardiac arrest.
3. Low-grade fevers: The patient's fevers can increase, leading to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
4. Labile blood pressure: The patient's labile blood pressure can lead to hypotension, which can cause organ failure and death.
5. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's poor control of DM can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis, which can cause coma, seizures, and death.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic cough and bronchitis can lead to respiratory failure, which can cause death.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to organ failure and death.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia can worsen, leading to bleeding and organ failure.
9. Kidney damage: The patient's kidney damage can worsen, leading to kidney failure and death.
10. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can worsen, leading to organ failure and death.

The patient's medications include metoprolol, diltiazem, haldol, ativan, and omeprazole, which may interact with each other and increase the risk of adverse effects.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated LFTs, elevated troponin, and low platelet count, which may indicate underlying organ damage.

The patient's physical examination shows tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension, which may indicate underlying organ failure.

The patient's nutritional status is ISS, which may indicate malnutrition and increased risk of complications.

The patient's lines include a 22-gauge line, which may increase the risk of infection.

The patient's prophylactic medications include heparin and omeprazole, which may increase the risk of bleeding and infection.

The patient's code status is "full code," which means that the patient is willing to receive all possible life-saving interventions.

The patient's disposition is ICU, which means that the patient will continue to receive care in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 77-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, who presented to the emergency department with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and obstructive liver function tests (LFTs) concerning for cholangitis.

The patient underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with sphincterotomy and stent placement, and his RUQ pain and LFTs have improved. He is currently receiving antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.

The patient is also experiencing atrial fibrillation (AF) with rapid ventricular rate (RVR), which is being treated with metoprolol and diltiazem. He has a history of recent gastrointestinal (GI) bleed and is at risk for bleeding due to his AF and use of anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's blood pressure (BP) has been labile, with episodes of hypertension and hypotension, which have been managed with fluid boluses and medication adjustments.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, anemia, and dyslipidemia, and he has a history of prostate cancer and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Cholangitis: The patient's RUQ pain and LFTs have improved, but he is at risk for recurrent cholangitis and sepsis.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's AF with RVR is being treated, but he is at risk for stroke, heart failure, and bleeding due to his anticoagulation therapy.
3. Gastrointestinal bleed: The patient's history of recent GI bleed and use of anticoagulation therapy put him at risk for further bleeding.
4. Hypertension: The patient's labile BP and use of antihypertensive medications make him at risk for hypotension and cardiovascular events.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease, but he is at risk for further anemia and bleeding due to his GI history and anticoagulation therapy.
6. Dyslipidemia: The patient's dyslipidemia is being managed with statin therapy, but he is at risk for further lipid disorders and cardiovascular events.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current conditions, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 77-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of RUQ pain and obstructive liver function tests (LFTs) concerning for cholangitis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 10.2-13.4 K/uL
* Hct: 31.0-33.2%
* Plt: 130-273 K/uL
* Cr: 0.9-1.0 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01-0.03 ng/mL
* TCO2: 24 mmHg
* Glucose: 72-114 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.3/27.6/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 59/3/0.02, ALT/AST: 20/22, Alk Phos/T Bili: 69/0.3, Amylase/Lipase: 56/26, Differential-Neuts: 81.2%, Lymph: 9.9%, Mono: 8.5%, Eos: 0.3%, Lactic Acid: 1.4 mmol/L, Albumin: 3.5 g/dL, LDH: 309 IU/L, Ca++: 7.8 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 1.8 mg/dL

The patient's vital signs are:

* Tmax: 37.3C (99.1F)
* Tcurrent: 36.1C (97F)
* HR: 102 bpm (88-132 bpm)
* BP: 157/82 mmHg (97-178/83 mmHg)
* RR: 24 inspirations per minute (15-29 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 98%

The patient has several potential medical complications that need to be monitored and managed:

1. Cholangitis: The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, and he has a history of cholecystitis. He is at risk for further complications, such as sepsis, organ failure, and death.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has developed atrial fibrillation, which is a potential complication of his underlying cardiac disease. He is at risk for stroke, heart failure, and arrhythmia.
3. Low-grade fevers: The patient's temperature has been mildly elevated, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions or an infection.
4. Labile blood pressure: The patient has experienced hypertension and hypotension, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions or medication side effects.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 33%, which is below the normal range. He is at risk for further complications, such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance.
6. Potential thyroid nodule: The patient's laboratory results show elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels, which may indicate a thyroid nodule or other thyroid disorder.
7. Tobacco abuse: The patient is a smoker, which increases his risk for respiratory and cardiovascular complications.
8. Dyslipidemia: The patient has a history of dyslipidemia, which is a potential risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and laboratory results, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to assess for any changes or complications.
2. Manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with rate control medications and monitor his heart rhythm.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and manage any episodes of hypertension or hypotension.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's thyroid function and consider further evaluation if necessary.
6. Counsel the patient regarding tobacco cessation and offer nicotine replacement therapy.
7. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's dyslipidemia.
8. Monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust his insulin regimen as necessary.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including cholangitis, atrial fibrillation, low-grade fevers, labile blood pressure, anemia, and potential thyroid nodule. He requires close monitoring and management of his underlying medical conditions to prevent further complications and improve his overall health.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86.3 kg male with a chief complaint of cholecystitis. The patient experienced confusion and delirium yesterday afternoon and evening, which improved with Haldol and benzodiazepine. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 137/63 mmHg.

The patient has several medical conditions, including atrial fibrillation, likely due to underlying coronary artery disease, which is suspected to be causing the troponin leak. The patient also has cholangitis, cholescystitis, and pancreatitis, which are being treated with antibiotics and supportive care.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, lipase, and troponin, as well as abnormal electrolyte levels, including hypokalemia. The patient's complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 13.4 K/uL and a platelet count of 273 K/uL.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Cholecystitis and cholangitis: Empirical Unasyn treatment, and clinical improvement.
* Atrial fibrillation: Control rate with lopressor, and consider anticoagulation.
